Journal.Title: The Central African journal of medicine

Article.ArticleTitle: Hypotensive effect of crude extract Olea. africana (Oleaceae) in normo and hypertensive rats.

AbstractText: To investigate the effects of crude extracts of the root and stem of Olea africana on mean arterial pressure (MAP) and heart rate in normo and hypertensive rats.

40 Sprague Dawley rats of either sex (150 to 250 g) randomly assigned to normotensive (n = 15) (DOCA) -salt hypertensive (n = 25) groups. The normotensive group comprised three subgroups (n = 5) namely, a control treated with graded volumes of normal saline intravenously (i.v.), and two groups respectively treated with graded doses of aqueous extract of O. africana (i.v.). The hypertensive group comprised five subgroups (n = 5) namely, a control group of sham operated rats, and four groups of nephrectomised rats. One group of nephrectomized rats received Deoxycorticosterone acetate (DOCA) and salt for seven days, while others received DOCAsalt for 14 days. Two groups of the 14 day treated rats respectively received 200 mg/kg and 1,000 mg/kg of O. africana orally thereafter. MAP and HR were measured under sodium pentobarbital anaesthesia (35 mg/kg intraperitoneally).
Mean arterial pressure and heart rate.

Intravenous administration of aqueous and ethanolic extracts of O. africana caused an immediate and dose dependent fall in MAP and HR in anaesthetised normotensive rats. The aqueous extract was more potent than the ethanolic extract. Orally administered aqueous extract produced lowering of MAP and HR in DOCA-salt hypertensive rats. Propranolol partially blocked the Map lowering effect of O. africana.

Extracts of O. africana lowered MAP and HR in normotensive and DOCA-salt hypertensive rats. Hence the use of the aqueous extracts in the treatment of some forms of hypertension and heart palpitations in humans. This effect may be mediated via beta adrenergic receptors.
